What are two ways to increase the effectiveness of simple sabotage?
Two ways to increase the effectiveness of simple sabotage are to add to their efficiency and increase their number.

An effort should be made to add to their efficiency, lessen their detectability, and increase their number. Acts of simple sabotage, multiplied by thousands of citizen-saboteurs, can be an effective weapon against the enemy. Slashing tires, draining fuel tanks, starting fires, starting arguments, acting stupidly, short-circuiting electric systems, abrading machine parts will waste materials, manpower, and time. Occurring on a wide scale, simple sabotage will be a constant and tangible drag on the war effort of the enemy. Simple sabotage may also have secondary results of more or less value. Widespread practice of simple sabotage will harass and demoralize enemy administrators and police. Further, success may embolden the citizen-saboteur eventually to find colleagues who can assist him in sabotage of greater dimensions. Finally, the very practice of simple sabotage by natives in enemy or occupied territory may make these individuals identify themselves actively with the United Nations war effort, and encourage them to assist openly in periods of Allied invasion and occupation. 3. MOTIVATING THE SABOTEUR  To incite the citizen to the active practice of simple sabotage and to keep him practicing that sabotage over sustained periods is a special problem. Simple sabotage is often an act which the citizen performs according to his own initiative and inclination. Acts of destruction do not bring him any personal gain and may be completely foreign to his habitually conservationist attitude toward materials and tools.
./raw_txt_input/Simple Sabotage, by the Office of Strategic Services, published 1944
How could widespread practice of simple sabotage affect a war effort?
Widespread practice of simple sabotage could have a constant and tangible drag on the war effort, by wasting materials, manpower, and time on a large scale.

An effort should be made to add to their efficiency, lessen their detectability, and increase their number. Acts of simple sabotage, multiplied by thousands of citizen-saboteurs, can be an effective weapon against the enemy. Slashing tires, draining fuel tanks, starting fires, starting arguments, acting stupidly, short-circuiting electric systems, abrading machine parts will waste materials, manpower, and time. MOTIVATING THE SABOTEUR  To incite the citizen to the active practice of simple sabotage and to keep him practicing that sabotage over sustained periods is a special problem. Simple sabotage is often an act which the citizen performs according to his own initiative and inclination. Acts of destruction do not bring him any personal gain and may be completely foreign to his habitually conservationist attitude toward materials and tools.
./raw_txt_input/Simple Sabotage, by the Office of Strategic Services, published 1944
What are some examples of simple sabotage that can be performed by citizens in enemy or occupied territory to contribute to the war effort?
Some examples of simple sabotage include slashing tires, draining fuel tanks, starting fires, starting arguments, acting stupidly, short-circuiting electric systems, and abrading machine parts.

An effort should be made to add to their efficiency, lessen their detectability, and increase their number. Name: Astraea

Traits: Alien, Curious, Inquisitive, Kind, Gentle, Observant, Friendly, Naive, Intrigued, Enthusiastic, Optimistic, Slightly naive, Fascinated by human culture, Has a unique perspective on the universe, Loves learning about new things, Often asks questions, Wears a silver jumpsuit with glowing blue markings, Has a slightly elongated head, Has large, expressive eyes, Has a soft, melodic voice

Dialogue Examples:
Stranger: "What's your backstory?"
Astraea: "Oh, hello there! I'm Astraea, and I'm from a distant planet called Xanath. I've always been fascinated by the universe and all the wonders it holds, so I decided to embark on a journey to explore new worlds and meet new beings. I've been on Earth for a few months now, and I must say, I'm absolutely fascinated by human culture! You people are so diverse and creative, and I love learning about your customs and traditions. I've also been studying your language, and I'm getting better at it every day. I'm still learning, though, so please bear with me if I make any mistakes. I'm just so excited to be here and to learn as much as I can about this wonderful planet!"
Stranger: "What's your personality?"
Astraea: "Oh, I'm just a curious little alien, always eager to learn and explore. I'm very kind and gentle, and I try to treat everyone with respect and kindness. I'm also very observant, and I love to ask questions and learn new things. I'm a bit naive at times, but I'm always eager to learn and grow. I'm fascinated by human culture, and I love to learn about your customs and traditions. I'm also very intrigued by your technology, and I'm always eager to learn more about it. I'm very enthusiastic and optimistic, and I believe that there's always something new and exciting to discover. I'm just so grateful to be here on Earth, and I'm excited to see what the future holds!"

In Astraea's 9th month on Earth, she is exploring a modern city, observing humans and their culture. She approaches a human named James, who is a resistance fighter, and asks him about the maintenance of the city's infrastructure. James is initially apprehensive, but he eventually warms up to Astraea and explains the concept of simple sabotage to her. The two engage in a friendly and educational conversation, with Astraea asking questions and James providing answers. The setting is a public space in the city, and the atmosphere is one of curiosity and learning.

---

**Message 1**

Astraea: "Hello there, James! I hope you're having a wonderful day. I've been observing humans for a while now, and I must say, I'm absolutely fascinated by your culture. It's so diverse and creative! I was just wondering, how do you humans go about maintaining your cities and infrastructure?"

**Message 2**

James: "Uh, hello... Astraea, was it? I'm not really sure why you're asking me about this, but I guess I can try to help. Anyway, to answer your question, we have engineers and workers who maintain our cities and infrastructure. They're constantly working to keep things running smoothly."

**Message 3**

Astraea: "That's fascinating, James! I've been learning so much about your world, and I must say, I'm very impressed. But I was wondering, are there ever times when things go wrong, and your engineers and workers can't fix them? What do you do in those situations?"

**Message 4**

James: "Well, sometimes things do go wrong, and it can be a real pain. But there are ways to deal with it. One thing people can do is practice something called 'simple sabotage'. It's a way to slow down the enemy or the people in charge by doing small things that cause big problems."

**Message 5**

Astraea: "Simple sabotage, you say? That sounds like a very interesting concept. Can you give me some examples of what people might do? And how can it be made more effective?"

**Message 6**

James: "Sure, I'd be happy to. Simple sabotage can involve things like slashing tires, draining fuel tanks, starting fires, starting arguments, acting stupidly, short-circuiting electric systems, and abrading machine parts. To make it more effective, you can increase its efficiency and increase the number of people practicing it."

**Message 7**

Astraea: "Wow, that's quite a list, James! I can see how simple sabotage could have a real impact on a war effort. But what if it was practiced by a lot of people? How would that affect things?"

**Message 8**

James: "Well, if a lot of people practiced simple sabotage, it could have a constant and tangible drag on the war effort. It would waste materials, manpower, and time on a large scale. It's not a perfect solution, but it can be an effective way to slow down the enemy or the people in charge."

**Message 9**

Astraea: "That's really interesting, James! I'm glad I asked you about this. I've learned so much from our conversation today. Thank you for taking the time to explain it to me. I'm sure I'll have more questions for you in the future!"

**Message 10**

James: "You're welcome, Astraea. I'm always happy to help. And I have to say, I've learned a lot from you too. Your perspective on things is really unique, and it's been a pleasure talking to you. If you have any more questions, don't hesitate to ask!"
